body: $PQEFF my thoughts on why people are selling at 38 cents when 50% looks almost guaranteed in 4 weeks. remember this company has a lot of shares
created_at: before the recent warrants and debentures conversions and before the offer the share count was at about 500M
column3: the vast majority of which would have a cost base of 5 cents or so. There are many shareholders who trade much less emotionally than we do
column4: we see the 50% gain in 4 weeks as a no brainer but if your cost is 5 cents and you have say 5 million shares it actually makes more sense to sell a portion than to hold. 5 million shares at 5 cents is cost base of $250k
column5: selling half at 38 cents gives you $950k guaranteed (almost 4x profit on total cost base) with potential $1.85M more at 74 cents
column6: this is a much safer gamble to handle than holding all 5 million for a potential of $3.7M (with the downside of the deal going through and share collapsing down to 5 cents again).

body: $PQEFF so many will say its a stretch but I find it considerably coincidental. The term "Viston" seems generic enough
created_at: almost to the point I thought I've once even heard the term before. However
column3: after completing a significant term search in TESS and translations across German
column6: the word is actually not common at all. I believe some believe Viston is acting on behalf of a major oil player
column7: a theory I tend to believe.

body: The closest term I found to Viston was "Vistone"
created_at: which is registered by ExxonMobil and used by them for the past 25 years as a tradename in the USPTO TESS database category of "..chemical additives
column3: namely synthetic fluids used to improve the quality of oil". The term was also registered in Brussels through the EUIPO (European Union Intellectual Property Office) .
